node.title: Bald eagle population growth stunted by lead poisoning, study finds
node.description: A study found the birds are eating hunters' gunshot ammunition, decreasing their population growth by 4 to 6%.
node.content: ["Bald eagles' population size is being affected by lead poisoning, according to scientists at the Department of Public and Ecosystem Health at Cornell University. A study found the birds are eating hunters' gunshot ammunition, decreasing their population growth by 4 to 6%.", "For the study, published in the Journal of Wildlife Management,\u00a0scientists looked at population regrowth numbers for\u00a0bald eagle populations\u00a0across the Northeast. They found that hunters who \"field dress\" their prey and leave the contaminated organs on site put the eagles that scavenge the remains at risk. Other species, including owls, crows, coyotes, foxes, fisher and bears, eat the remains as well, meaning they are all possibly at risk of being poisoned.\u00a0", "\"We haven't collected data on these other species in the same way that we pay attention to eagles,\" Schuler said. \"We're putting eagles out there as a poster species for this issue, but they're not the only ones being impacted.\"", "Even humans may be affected if they eat a game species with lead fragments in it.", "The research team hoped that the information would inform hunters \u2014 and political policy \u2014 on ammunition choices, such as copper-based ammunition.\u00a0", "The bald eagles' diminished growth rates have the ability to undo a \"cushion\" for the population, which would protect them against unforeseen events like natural disasters or West Nile virus that could decimate the population, the researchers said.\u00a0", "The eagles' population, which was once threatened by the use of DDT during World War II, had begun to rebound after the 1973\u00a0Endangered Species Act\u00a0was enacted. In fact, their population size in the lower 48 quadrupled between 2009 and 2021.", "However, scientists estimated that bald eagle growth rates were suppressed by 4.2% for females, and 6.3% for males.", "\"Even though the population seems like it's recovered, some perturbation could come along that could cause eagles to decline again,\" Schuler said.", "FORMER COPY:", "Bald eagle populations plummeted after World War II decimated their numbers, primarily due to the use of DDT. The species began to heal when the the\u00a0Endangered Species Act\u00a0when it was enacted in 1973, and population growth has scientists optimistic. But scientists at the Department of Public and Ecosystem Health at Cornell University have uncovered another hurdle for the beloved birds to overcome \u2014 lead poisoning.\u00a0", "The\u00a0new study, published in the Journal of Wildlife Management, lays out the scientists' findings on population regrowth numbers for bald eagle populations across the Northeast. The study found that despite numbers increasing, poisoning from bald eagles eating dead carcasses or parts contaminated by lead shot from hunters has reduced population growth by 4 to 6%.\u00a0", "The research team hopes that this information will help inform hunters \u2014 and political policy \u2014 on ammunition choices, such as copper-based ammunition. The scientists recognized that any type of ammunition is hard to find due to supply chain issues from COVID-19 complications.\u00a0", "\"Hopefully, this report will add information that compels hunters, as conservationists, to think about their ammunition choices,\" said Krysten Schuler, assistant research professor in the \u00ad\u00adDepartment of Public and Ecosystem Health at Cornell University and senior author in a press release.", "The diminished growth rates, which may seem small, have the ability to undo a \"cushion\" for the bald eagle population, which would protect them against unforeseen events like natural disasters or West Nile virus that could decimate the population, the researchers said.\u00a0", "While bald eagle numbers have scientists hopeful, with population size quadrupling between 2009 to 2021, the researcher's findings on lead's impact on eagles also points to negative outcomes for other important species that don't have the bald eagle's name recognition.", "\"We haven't collected data on these other species in the same way that we pay attention to eagles,\" Schuler said. \"We're putting eagles out there as a poster species for this issue, but they're not the only ones being impacted.\"", "Even human health may be affected when lead fragments from bullets that are left inside game species are consumed.", "Lead ammunition can be left in bald eagle's habitat when hunters \"field dress\" their prey,\u00a0 and leave the contaminated organs where the animal was shot. Bald eagles will scavenge from these entrails, as well as owls, crows, coyotes, foxes, fisher and bears, who are all at risk of lead poisoning.\u00a0", "The scientists estimated that bald eagle growth rates were suppressed by 4.2% for females, and 6.3% for males.", "\"Even though the population seems like it's recovered, some perturbation could come along that could cause eagles to decline again,\" Schuler said.", "For Breaking News & Analysis Download the Free CBS News app"]
